When thinking about studying abroad, one of the first things that come to mind is likely to be housing, and your final decision will be influenced by a variety of factors. When it comes to international student housing, there are many options to consider, as well as a number of considerations and checkpoints to go through before making your decision, which is certain to be somewhat dependent on personal preference. Whatever your budget, there will be a housing alternative for you, whether it be university accommodation or private sector housing.

As an international student, you may be living on your own for the first time, or perhaps traveling abroad. It could also be your first time managing expenses and dealing with any part of lodging.

As a result, it’s critical to recognize right away that this is a serious decision. Your student housing will be a place for you to unwind, study, and, most importantly, make new friends, locals, and fellow travelers. Once you’ve been accepted to your preferred university, you should start looking for housing for the first year of your program. It’s crucial to make sure you’re prepared for your arrival at a university overseas, in addition to obtaining your visa. Different types of student housing


Depending on where you want to study, your options for student housing may be extensive and provide a wide range of experiences. You’ll also discover that finding a place to stay in some nations is as simple as falling off a log, while in others you’ll need to plan ahead of time and often spend more than you anticipated. Some universities offer first-year overseas students housing as a guarantee. To ensure your spot, you’ll still have to satisfy rigorous requirements for confirming and paying a deposit.

On-campus housing

Staying in on-campus halls of residence can help you get the most out of your academic experience. Apart from the convenience of being close to classrooms, it encourages students to interact with one another more frequently and participate in campus activities and groups.

Meal plans are frequently included in the cost of halls of residence. Breakfast and dinner, or possibly every meal, may be included in the accommodation rate.

It’s crucial to understand that, as is common at American universities, campus housing can sometimes mean sharing a dorm room with other students. The majority of students in the United Kingdom, on the other hand, have their own room but may share bathroom and kitchen facilities.

Off-campus Housing

Some universities do not have a single campus, therefore student housing is dispersed around a town or city. An external company specializing in university housing, on the other hand, may offer alternatives for various universities in a city. In some situations, you may find yourself living off-campus yet in specialized student housing.

This setup is typically similar to on-campus halls of residence, but it is not tied to one. It will be in a good student neighborhood, with many amenities and convenient access to institutions.

This type of housing may allow you to meet and live with students from other universities or levels of study. If the institution does not run the lodging, it may recommend a company that does.

Renting for international students

International students may have difficulties while renting privately, particularly when attempting to arrange housing from outside the country.

It can be tough to organize in your first year of school due to a lack of awareness of a country’s legal process for renting and not being there to see homes. It’s also crucial to be cautious of any rental scams targeting overseas students.

Your chosen university should be able to help you find a suitable home by proposing firms or landlords, as well as any legal issues that may occur, such as establishing your identity.

Before you sign a rental agreement, be sure the company or landlord is reputable and that the house you’re renting is in a good student neighborhood. Because students generally live in the same neighborhoods of a town or city, this is usually easy to find out.
